newsitem.title: CHINA: China B shares end easier in shadow of Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: China B shares end easier in shadow of Hong Kong.

text.p: China's B shares for foreigners closed easier on Thursday as investors kept to the sidelines or switched funds to the red-hot Hong Kong market, brokers said.
B shares lost ground on both the big bourse in Shanghai and the southern exchange in Shenzhen while A stocks for domestic investors were mixed.
The Shanghai B index edged down a negligible 0.028 point to 72.903 as turnover shrank to $3.931 million from $4.330 million on Wednesday. In Shenzhen, the B share index slipped 0.44 point to 129.60.
"As major investors were sidelined, trading was very sluggish despite some bargain-hunting," said a broker.

The listless trade failed to gain a lift from news that economic tsar Zhu Rongji had urged lumbering state firms to look to the share market as a means to raise capital rather than relying on bank credits.
"The positive news failed to activate the B share market, as major investors are trading in Hong Kong," a broker said.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index powered 2.39 percent higher to another record close, reaching 16,365.71 on Thursday.
Shanghai Huili Building Materials was the biggest loser on expectations it will report disappointing interim profits. It shed $0.020 or 9.52 percent to $0.190 on volume of 332,000 shares.
Shanghai Refrigerator Compressor was the most active issue, rebounding from recent losses. It gained $0.010 or 2.57 percent to $0.398 on volume of 921,300 shares.
In Shenzhen, Jiangling Motors absorbed the biggest loss as it slid HK$0.19 or 6.88 percent to HK$2.57 in thin trade.
Shanghai's A share index extended its recent upward climb on active buying of a handful of companies. It gained 11.122 points or 0.90 percent to 1,245.578.

Yizheng Chemical Fibre surged 0.28 yuan or 5.97 percent to 4.97 yuan. Brokers linked the rise to rumours the company would merge with another manufacturer or announce a restructuring but an Yizheng spokesman said there was no such plan.
Yizheng also has shares listed in Hong Kong and those shares were suspended from trading pending an announcement.
In Shenzhen, the A share index lost 0.23 point to 407.49, pressured by light profit-taking.
